node.title: Yellen: Labor force participation "quite depressed" compared to pre-COVID
node.description: Yellen pointed to several reasons for an "abnormally low" supply of labor.
node.content: ["The uneven job recovery \u2014 namely a shortage of workers \u2014 is a direct result of the pandemic, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen told \"Face the Nation\" moderator Margaret Brennan in an exclusive interview Friday.\u00a0", "\"When we really get control of the pandemic, I think labor supply will go back to normal,\" Yellen predicted.\u00a0", "Yellen pointed to several reasons for an \"abnormally low\" supply of labor \u2014 including a shortage of childcare workers and educators, which \"creates childcare problems.\"\u00a0", "\"That also tends to suppress labor supply,\" Yellen said.\u00a0", "The U.S. economy has had more than 10 million open jobs since June, according to data released Friday by the Labor Department. More than six million Americans who lost their jobs in April 2020 still have not returned to the labor force. \u00a0", "Yellen, who is a labor economist, is dealing with other problems as the administration battles rising inflation and supply chain snarls. The administration argues the $1.2 trillion infrastructure package \u2014 which the House passed last week \u2014 will slow rapid price increases but not all economists agree.", "President Biden is expected to sign the infrastructure bill on Monday. There are concerns about what it will do to inflation.\u00a0", "\"It will create millions of new jobs, it'll grow the economy and we'll win the world economic competition that we're engaged in,\" Mr. Biden said before his cabinet meeting Friday.\u00a0", "But, with the Build Back Better plan, which is still being negotiated in Congress, the administration thinks it is a solution to broader labor issues.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
